facts.text: Dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal, Rajasthan under section 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 relating to workmen's demand for bonus for the years 1956-57 to 1959-60.
Tribunal's award dated May 4, 1964 disallowed claim for 1956-57 as belated and allowed demand for 1957-58 to 1959-60.
Gross profits: Rs. 28.29 lacs for 1957-58, Rs. 25.36 lacs for 1958-59, Rs. 34.92 lacs for 1959-60. No dispute about these figures.
Company has been purchasing new and old reconditioned machinery since commencement.

Cost to Company and estimated cost to sellers if purchased as new for old machinery: Upto 1952-53: 13.87 lacs / 20.05 lacs; 1953-54 to 1955-56: 3.49/5.23; 1956-57:1.40/2.10; 1957-58:1.77/2.65. Total old: 20.03/30.03 lacs.

Union did not dispute: costs to Company of new machinery (Ex. M2), costs of old machinery to Company and estimated to sellers (Ex. M3), quotations of prices in 1963-64 except for machinery installed during bonus years.
Tribunal worked out rehabilitation requirements in Annexure A using multipliers for new and old machinery.
Company produced quotations for equivalent machinery current in 1963-64.
Tribunal allowed 6% tax free interest for 1957-58 and 1958-59, mean of 7.25% for 1959-60 on paid-up capital.
No interest on working capital as no reserve utilised as such.
Machinery worked on three shifts since 1955-56 for precision machines.
Entire machinery needed immediate replacement, accepted by Tribunal.
Depreciation written off upto 31-3-57: Rs. 48.83 lacs.
Company's fixed assets value about Rs. 110 lacs, subscribed capital Rs. 60 lacs, debenture loan Rs. 50 lacs.
Investment in stocks and shares Rs. 18.22 lacs as of 1956-57.
Balance-sheet 1956-57 published December 1957, accounts closed by end 1957.
Bonus claim raised by Union resolution July 24, 1959.
Machinery discarded 1959-60: Rs. 17.62 lacs plant/machinery, Rs. 8.57 lacs tools.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Tribunal correctly calculated rehabilitation allowances for plant and machinery, particularly multipliers for old machinery and method of using quotations.
Whether interest on paid-up capital for 1959-60 should be 6% or higher.
Whether claim for bonus 1956-57 was belated.
Average life of machinery: 15 years or 25 years.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal should accept quotations as replacement cost for old machinery instead of hypothetical multipliers, leading to higher rehab cost of Rs. 121.70 lacs vs 85.62 lacs, wiping out surplus.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Full Bench formula as in Millowners Association v. Radhtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh and Associated Cement Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Multipliers for old machinery should be based on ratio of estimated cost to seller and quotations: 1950-51 3.98, etc.
Rs. 48.83 lacs depreciation not fully available as utilised in fixed assets; Rs. 18.22 lacs investment not available.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: G. F. Mills v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Interest on paid-up capital for 1959-60 should be 8.57% due to change in Income-tax law.
Graduated divisor for remainder life of old machinery, not uniform 7.

respondent_arguments.text: Multipliers necessary; cost during bonus years relevant; quotations for 1963-64 not sole criterion.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Associated Cement Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

respondent_arguments.text: Life of new machinery 25 years, not 15.
Quotations include spares and possibly expansion; exclude cost of expansion.
Rs. 48.83 lacs depreciation available as subscribed capital and loans cover fixed assets.

respondent_arguments.legal_basis: South India Millowners Association v. Coimbatore District Textile Workers Union

court_reasoning.text: Where cost of replacement available through undisputed quotations, no need for hypothetical multiplier; apply same method to old as new machinery using estimated cost to seller and quotations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Replacement cost Rs. 121.70 lacs vs Tribunal's 85.62 lacs, difference Rs. 36.08 lacs.

court_reasoning.text: Quotations best evidence of probable replacement cost; not limited to bonus year prices.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Project price level into future using subsequent prices.

court_reasoning.text: Burden on employer to show no expansion in replacement costs; Company discharged via evidence, experts, cross-exam.
Uniform divisor 7 incorrect; use graduated based on 10-year life for old machinery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Remainder life varies by installation year.

court_reasoning.text: Rs. 48.83 lacs depreciation available; Company itself deducted similar in Ex. M-4.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence Rs. 30 lacs utilised in fixed assets.

court_reasoning.text: Rs. 18.22 lacs investment available as capital asset convertible to cash.
15-year life correct given precision industry, three shifts.
Claim 1956-57 belated by 18 months after accounts closed.
Recalculated available surplus: Nil for 1957-58, 1958-59, 1959-60 after higher rehab.

holdings.text: Tribunal erred in calculating rehabilitation costs for old machinery; use quotations directly or correct multipliers, leading to no available surplus.
Bonus claim for 1956-57 rightly rejected as belated.

outcome.summary: Company's appeal allowed, Tribunal's direction for payment of bonus for 1957-58 to 1959-60 set aside as no available surplus after correct rehabilitation calculation. Workmen's appeal dismissed. Parties to bear own costs.

key_quotes.text: "But where the cost of replacement is available through quotations and these quotations are not disputed by the Union it would not be necessary to resort to a hypothetical multiplier"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on using quotations for old machinery

key_quotes.text: "The test is the probable cost of replacement when rehabilitation becomes due"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "payment of bonus is in recognition of the contribution of labour in the profits earned by the industry"
key_quotes.speaker: court
